Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Sarah Trimpin of Wayne State University is supported by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry to explore the recently discovered ion generation method for mass spectrometry, matrix-assisted ionization in vacuum. Mass spectrometric analysis requires the sample molecules to be volatilized and electrically charged (ionized) so that they can be identified according to the way they behave in the magnetic and/or electric field of the instrument. While traditional methods of sample ionization require electron beams, lasers, or other energetic processes, the Trimpin laboratory will develop methods wherein chemical samples can be volatilized and ionized simply by exposure to vacuum conditions. The better we understand how the ion generation processes work the better we can exploit them for biomolecular analysis, the major application of contemporary mass spectrometry. During the course of conducting this research, graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral researchers will gain valuable skills in mass spectrometry instrumentation and its applications in biochemical analysis. The outreach plans include participation in active recruitment of women, members of underrepresented minorities and undergraduates through Wayne State University initiatives to enhance diversity in academic programs.

The objectives of the proposed research are organized in three specific aims: (1) to determine the mechanism of matrix-assisted ionization in vacuum (MAIV) and the physical processes that occur when matrices with analytes are exposed to conditions that spontaneously produce analyte ions by studying the fundamentals of ion formation with optical methods, atomic force microscopy, microbalance, and high speed photography; (2) to obtain a predictive understanding of how MAIV matrices function in relation to pressure, temperature and solvent conditions.; and (3) to explore the potential analytical applications of MAIV in biological mass spectrometry, mass spectrometry imaging, and in portable mass spectrometers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Chemical Measurement Imaging 1411376 award was instrumental in the discovery and advancement of novel ionization technologies used with mass spectrometry for detecting and identifying the molecular composition of synthetic and biological materials.  The new processes for converting volatile and nonvolatile compounds into gas-phase ions for analysis by mass spectrometry have outperformed, in key analyses, technologies whose inventors received a portion of the 2002 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, and which have been optimized in laboratories worldwide over the past 30 years.  This significant accomplishment was achieved through efforts related to acquiring a fundamental understanding of the novel ionization processes, building dedicated ion sources, and applying this technology in collaborative efforts world-wide to address analysis problems which had not been resolved using conventional mass spectrometric methods.  One example is direct analyses showing the molecular composition of inorganic catalytic complexes applied as a single monolayer to a surface. Key advancement in elucidating the molecular composition of materials were made possible by the discovery and improvements in our understanding of a heretofore unknown ionization process based on unanticipated properties of sublimation.  Certain small molecule compounds (matrices), which all have the property that they sublime upon exposure to sub-atmospheric pressure, produce gas-phase ions from associated compounds, manmade or biological, when simply exposed to the vacuum inherent with all mass spectrometers. In traditional ionization methods, lasers, ion beams, or high voltage have been used to achieve gaseous ions from nonvolatile compounds, but with the new ionization process, gas-phase ions are produced under conditions in which sublimation of the small molecule matrix occurs.  Besides requiring no external energy source, the new method is unmatched by traditional ionization technologies in its robustness, simplicity, and ease of use, and, for some compound types, surpasses these methods in sensitivity. Our results transform not only our understanding of charge separation processes used for ionization in mass spectrometry, but also our knowledge of processes related to sublimation under certain conditions.  The gained knowledge achieved through this award provided enlightened insights into the mechanisms of the new and traditional ionization processes used in mass spectrometry, and has the potential to open new areas of applications such as medical diagnostics and biological threat detection. The simplicity and ease of use resulting in lower cost combined with robustness to failure and instrument contamination, as well as speed of analyses and low chemical background suggests the method will be instrumental in driving mass spectrometry in areas such as clinical analyses where these attributes are especially important.  There is still much to be learned about this astonishing ionization process, and its full potential in terms of applications is likely in its infancy. We are confident that this enabling ionization process and associated technologies will have a lasting impact in many areas of science and medicine.  The ionization discoveries are receiving widespread interest, applicability, and further innovations by other groups world-wide. In the NSF CMI funding period, the PI?s group has produced 15 peer-reviewed research papers (with several additional manuscripts to be submitted), 1 book chapter, 9 reviews and other invited contributions, licensed 3 out of 6 issued patents, presented at 31 national and international as well as 21 local and regional conferences by the PI, students and postdocs, and an additional 36 invited lectures at Departments and Conferences around the world by the PI, additionally to the commercialization efforts of the NSF-enabled inventions by the PI (CEO of university spin-off company MSTM, LLC).
